prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: IC 5332 Mosaic
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CO (2-1) and continuum mosaic of the active area of IC 5332.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
(Please note that we adopt a common strategy and justification across all science goals.)
We require high (~1 km/s) resolution and broad (~1000 km/s) coverage of the 12CO 2-1 line in order to capture the full emission from massive, moderately inclined galaxies and be able to measure detailed small-scale velocity gradients in the bright regions. This drives our spectral setup for the first window.
As discussed above, we target the C18O line as an excellent ancillary science goal. Due to the lower signal-to-noise we do not need the full 1 km/s resolution and average 4 times to lower the data rate.
The other two windows are set to observe continuum at much coarser resolution. With the C18O and bulk of the CO window we expect to manage approximately 6 GHz of effective continuum bandwidth.
Our observations are below the policy value of 12 MB/s.

(Please note that we adopt a common strategy and justification across all science goals.)
Our science goal is to understand the link small scale ISM physics to the behavior of whole galaxies. This requires that we reach the key ~60 pc scale of gravitational boundedness, turbulent energy injection, the disk scale height, etc. (see the main proposal). This is ~1 at the distance of our targets, which have been picked to maximize the ability to map large areas at high physical resolution (i.e., they are representative star-forming galaxies at 6-16 Mpc). This goal, matching a big cloud to a single resolution element, drives our angular resolution.
We know from our earlier work (Pety et al. 2013), many other studies (e.g., Helfer et al. 2003, Koda et al. 2009), and our own simulations using previous CO observations (particularly our 1 M51 CO map) that CO emission in galaxies has large amounts of power on large angular scales and that total power observations are essential. We see the same in our very recent CO 2-1 observations using ALMA targeting NGC 628 with the ACA and 12-m arrays. We set the largest angular scale to 30, where we know there is still large amounts of power from those maps. This triggers the requirement of the ACA in total power mode, which is key to our science goals.

(Please note that we adopt a common strategy and justification across all science goals.)
Our goals are to detect high mass individual clouds and clusters of low mass clouds in individual elements, to measure the extended structure of CO emission at high signal-to-noise, and to make target of opportunity measurements of C18O and the 1mm continuum.
POINT SOURCE SENSITIVITY: We target 7.5 mJy/beam per 5 km/s channel and aim to detect individual high mass clouds or clusters of low mass clouds. For a standard CO-to-H2 conversion factor (2e20 cm^-2/K km s^-1; r21=0.7) this yields sensitivity to individual high mass giant molecular clouds within a resolution element. For our median distance of 12 Mpc, S/N 3 corresponds to ~2e5 Msun (see Sandstrom et al. 2013 for CO 2-1 and Bolatto et al. 2013 for the formulae), about the mass of a high mass GMC, the sensitivity scales with distance as 1/D^2. We know from similar observations of NGC 628 (Schinnerer et al. in prep.; CO 2-1 from ALMA, similar set up to here) and M51 (Schinnerer et al. 2013) that this target sensitivity works in practice, yielding widespread detections (hundreds of clouds) in both cases, which span our activity range. For comparison this would capture 100-200 of the galactic ring clouds in the Milky Way.
EXTENDED SOURCE SENSITIVITY: In practice, CO emission has power on all scales with increasing power as one moves to shorter u-v spacings.Recovering this power is essential to any complete view of CO emission in galaxies, a point we discuss for M51 in Pety et al. (2013), where we show that including short spacing data accounts for 50% of the flux in M51. This makes the combination of 12m + ACA in total power mode essential. We have compared the uv baseline distribution to the power spectrum of a 1 M51 CO cube (Schinnerer et al. 2013) using CASA simdata and find that the combination C36-2, ACA 7m, and total power does an excellent job of recovering all emission (the same can be seen in the Technical Handbook exercise on broadband emission from M51). Concretely, we will recover all flux and be able to make maps with very high surface brightness sensitivity at resolutions coarser than 1 (and to include this emission in our 1 cube via multi-scale cleaning). We note that our team includes experts on this complex combination (especially co-I Pety). This approach gives us that ability, yielding rms noise ~20s mK at a ~3 resolution.
LINE WIDTH: The line width of 5 km/s is a typical CO velocity dispersion for a quiescent part of a galaxy disk (see Tamburro et al. 2009, Meidt et al. 2013). It closely resembles the dispersion found in PAWS. It is also about the line width of a typical giant molecular cloud (Heyer et al. 2009). It is therefore the appropriate fiducial value to consider detection of CO emission.
CONTINUUM: Continuum is a target of opportunity for the proposal. We do not expect widespread detections but it would be very useful if seen in galaxy centers. We allocate unused correlator resources to this goal with a low velocity resolution (low data rate) set up. With 6.5 GHz aggregate bandwidth and ~0.2 mJy/beam sensitivity we would expect to be able to detect dust wherever gas exceeds ~1000 Msun/pc^2 over a beam (e.g., following Draine et al. 2014). We don't expect this in all sources, but these values do arise in active galaxy centers and hotter dust may make detections easier.
C18O: We place the spectral window in upper part of the lower sideband in FDM mode to capture the C18O line (rest frequency ~219.5 GHz) as best we can without compromising our 12CO observations. Stacking and exploration of these data in the high surface brightness part of the observations (short baselines and ACA) will yield important science, though this is not our main goal. We do not expect detections at 1 resolution outside the centers of galaxies given that the line ratio with 12CO is usually quite high (e.g., Wilson \& Rood 1994).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Mapping molecular gas at individual cloud scales (~50 pc) over a large number of galaxies, sampling the diverse environments within them, is necessary to understand how the formation and disruption of GMCs, the efficiency of star formation, and the coupling of feedback to the ISM depend on local and global conditions, and how these processes affect the overall evolution of galaxies. We request 13.5 hours of ALMA main-array plus ACA+TP to produce deep CO(2-1) maps of nine nearby late-type sub-L* star-forming disk galaxies at ~1'' resolution. Late-type disks are sufficiently CO-bright to efficiently map molecular structures (in contrast to dwarf galaxies) and contain diverse dynamical, chemical, and stellar environments which differ from the standard conditions in high mass L* systems. We will explore the link between the multi-phase ISM, star formation, and feedback across a broad range of environments at cloud scale resolution for the first time, and will produce an exquisite legacy dataset for nearby galaxy studies from the southern hemisphere.
